events.title: The people betting on catastrophic world events â€“ podcast
events.description: Prediction markets allow you to put money on everything from the US attacking Iran to Jesus returning. Saahil Desai explains their dizzying rise In the early hours of 3 January, Donald Trump ordered a surprise attack on the Venezuelan capital, Caracas, to kidnap the countryâ€™s leader, NicolÃ¡s Maduro. Millions of Venezuelansâ€™ lives were thrown into uncertainty. Politicians at home and abroad scrambled to respond. It seemed this was something no one had seen coming. Except one person did actually predict it. In the hours before the attack, someone - and we have no way of knowing who - placed a series of bets that Donald Trump would oust Maduro on a prediction market platform, netting them nearly $500,000 when it happened. These platforms allow their users not just to bet on whoeverâ€™s going to win the Super Bowl, but also on world events. Heavily regulated under the Biden administration, these apps have enjoyed a huge boom in popularity since Trump came to power. Continue reading...

events.title: Mass weddings on the rise in Pakistan as poverty soars

Each year, tens of thousands of couples are forced to delay or abandon plans to marry. In response, mass weddings are multiplying across the country, cutting across religious communities. events.description: Genie Godula is pleased to welcome Stefan Wolff, Professor of International Security at the University of Birmingham. events.title: Germany news: Merz on Gulf tour talks arms deals in Doha
events.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz is on a three-day visit to the Gulf region as Germany seeks closer partnerships on business, energy and security. DW has the latest.

events.title: How a Jewish familyâ€™s Baghdad home became Franceâ€™s rent-free embassy
events.description: A Paris court on Monday dismissed a lawsuit brought by the descendants of an Iraqi Jewish family seeking compensation for a Baghdad villa occupied rent-free by France's diplomatic representation for decades. Forced to flee Iraq amid rising anti-Semitism in the late 1940s, the family said it will appeal the ruling.

events.title: Carney scraps Canada EV sales mandate, but earmarks funds to aid transition
events.description: Canadian Prime Minister â Mark Carney on Thursday scrapped a mandate for all vehicles sold in Canada to be electric by 2035, marking another retreat from emissions and climate-focused measures. At the same time, Carney also earmarked funds to bolster EV production in a bid to boost a Canadian auto industry hammered by US tariffs.

events.title: Israel charges brother of Shin Betâ€™s chief for smuggling goods into Gaza
events.description: Israeli prosecutors on Thursday filed charges against Bezalel Zini, brother of the chief of Israel's domestic intelligence agency Shin Bet, over the alleged smuggling of cigarettes into Gaza. Zini, a reservist in the Israeli military, is suspected of smuggling around $117,400 worth of cigarettes into the besieged Palestinian territory, where the entry of all goods and people is controlled by Israel.

events.title: Are we in an AI bubble?
events.description: Artificial intelligence is the next frontier â€“ but is it also the next bubble? That's the question investors have been asking since tech giants began investing billions of dollars in AI and driving stock market gains. We put the question to an expert.

events.title: Harris Dickinson on his film 'Urchin,' navigating Hollywood and channelling John Lennon
events.description: From "Babygirl" with Nicole Kidman to Cannes Palme d'Or winner "Triangle of Sadness", Harris Dickinson is one of Britain's most compelling actors and now one of its most exciting new directors. His debut film "Urchin" is a raw and tender portrait of a homeless addict in London. As the film is released in France, he talks to Laura Di Biasio about filming the London he knows, acting versus directing, and his upcoming role as Beatles icon John Lennon.

events.title: How to create the perfect romantic meal for your Valentine
events.description: If you're looking for a fun and tasty way to surprise your sweetheart for Valentine's Day this year, we have a great idea for you in this edition of Entre Nous. The famous Cordon Bleu Paris cooking school is marking the romantic holiday with two nights of dinners on Friday 13 and Saturday 14 February, to be held at the beautiful HÃ´tel de la Marine at the Place de la Concorde in Paris. Chef Instructor Guillaume Siegler tells us what the event is all about and how they came up with the romantic menu.

events.title: Irish artist Ailbhe NÃ­ Bhriain on her twin exhibitions in Paris
events.description: A renowned Irish artist who currently has two exhibitions showing in Paris has spoken to FRANCE 24 about her work. Ailbhe NÃ­ Bhriain is known for her big, bold dramatic works of art as she uses all sorts of materials including silk, wool, cotton and lurex. She aims to create what she calls an emblem of industry, empire and permanence. Her work is on display at the Irish Cultural Centre and the AndrÃ©hn Schiptjenko gallery here in Paris. She spoke to us in Perspective.

events.title: Sledgehammer-wielding robbers raid family jewellers

events.title: Don't boo the Americans, Olympics boss tells spectators

events.title: Wave of emotion as first Gazans return to their loved ones amid devastation
events.description: First came the cars of the United Nations, then two coaches with blue paintwork. And then came a wave of emotion - proof that the heart has a power that the head can't always match.

events.description: The reopening of the Rafah crossing in the southern Gaza Strip on Monday after more than a year is being met with both optimism and fear, a senior official with the UN agency that assists the Palestinian people, UNRWA, has said.

events.title: More than 200 people evaluated in Tennessee after carbon monoxide leak infiltrates university facility

events.description: The U.S., Ukrainian, and Russian delegations have agreed to an exchange of 314 prisoners, according to U.S. special envoy Steve Witkoff's office.
